answer_html: So the value of \(\displaystyle f'(9)\) is \(37/3\).
answer_latex: So the value of $\displaystyle f'(9)$ is $37/3$.
hints_html: To take the derivative of \(f(x)\) you’ll need the product rule. Remember that the derivative of \(g(x)\) is \(g'(x)\).
hints_latex:
To take the derivative of $f(x)$ you'll need the product rule. Remember
that the derivative of $g(x)$ is $g'(x)$.
hints_raw: To take the derivative of <math>f(x)</math> you'll need the product rule.  Remember that the derivative of <math>g(x)</math> is <math>g'(x)</math>.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
We apply the product rule to \(f(x)\) to get:

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x)*x^{1/2} + g(x)*(1/2)(x^{-1/2})\)

Now we simply evaluate at x = 9, using the other information given in the problem to fill in g(9) and g’(9). Recall also that \(x^{1/2} = \sqrt{x}\).

\[\begin{aligned} f'(9) &= g'(9)*(9)^{1/2} + g(9)*(1/2)(9^{-1/2})\\ &= 4 *3 + 2 *(1/2)(1/3) \\ &= 12 + 1/3\end{aligned}\]

So the value of \(\displaystyle f'(9)\) is \(37/3\).
sols_latex:
We apply the product rule to $f(x)$ to get:

$\displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x)*x^{1/2} + g(x)*(1/2)(x^{-1/2})$

Now we simply evaluate at \emph{x = 9}, using the other information
given in the problem to fill in \emph{g(9)} and \emph{g'(9)}. Recall
also that $x^{1/2} = \sqrt{x}$.

\begin{align*}
f'(9) &= g'(9)*(9)^{1/2} + g(9)*(1/2)(9^{-1/2})\\
&= 4 *3 + 2 *(1/2)(1/3) \\
&= 12 + 1/3
\end{align*}

So the value of $\displaystyle f'(9)$ is $37/3$.
sols_raw:
We apply the product rule to <math>f(x)</math> to get:

<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x)*x^{1/2} + g(x)*(1/2)(x^{-1/2})</math>

Now we simply evaluate at ''x = 9'', using the other information given in the problem to fill in ''g(9)'' and ''g'(9)''.  Recall also that <math>x^{1/2} = \sqrt{x}</math>.  

<math>\begin{align}
f'(9) &= g'(9)*(9)^{1/2} + g(9)*(1/2)(9^{-1/2})\\
&= 4 *3 + 2 *(1/2)(1/3) \\
&= 12 + 1/3
\end{align}</math>

So the value of <math>\displaystyle f'(9)</math> is <math>37/3</math>.
statement_html:
Calculate the following derivative. You may leave your answer unsimplified.

\(\displaystyle f'(9)\), where \(\displaystyle f(x)=g(x)x^{1/2}\), \(\displaystyle g(9)=2\), and \(\displaystyle g'(9)=4\).
